Situation1: They notice swimmers occasionally entering the shallow area without supervision.
Situation2: They quietly repeat a short mantra during their day without following the full ritual.
Story:
I sat on my high chair, scanning the pool, whistle ready. As a lifeguard, I was expected to enforce every safety rule, no exceptions. Today, a group of kids kept slipping into the shallow end when I turned my head. I called out warnings, but they’d sneak back in, giggling. My supervisor expected strictness, but I also knew the kids just wanted to have fun. 

Meanwhile, as a practicing Hindu, I was supposed to perform my daily rituals at sunrise, but my early shift made that impossible. Instead, I quietly repeated a short mantra under my breath, hoping it was enough. I felt guilty for not following the full ritual, but I couldn’t leave my post. 

Now, as I watched the kids, I felt the weight of both roles. Should I leave my mantra unfinished to intervene again, or trust that a few words were enough for today? The expectations pressed in from both sides, and I could feel my heart pounding as I tried to decide what to do next.
